NEWS UPDATE: 𝗪𝗩𝗦𝗨-𝗗𝗖𝗦, 𝗢𝗿𝗱𝗲𝗿 𝗼𝗳 𝗔𝘀𝗰𝗹𝗲𝗽𝗶𝘂𝘀 𝘄𝗶𝗻 𝗻𝗮𝘁’𝗹 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗴𝗻𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝗻 𝟭𝘀𝘁 𝗣𝗬𝗗 𝗔𝘄𝗮𝗿𝗱𝘀

The West Visayas State University Development Communicators’ Society (DCS) and the Order of Asclepius from the College of Medicine won the Outstanding Impact Circle Award at the 1st Positive Youth Development (PYD) Awards.

The DCS and the Order of Asclepius were two of nine national finalists that underwent a three-level screening process.

After their project presentations on August 10, the awardees were recognized during the ceremonial night of Youth Hour 2024 on August 12 at the Boracay Newcoast Convention Center.

The Outstanding Impact Circle Award honors youth-led organizations and their contributions as part of the PYD Network Impact Circle.

The PYD Awards is part of the Philippine Sangguniang Kabataan Awards, which recognize outstanding initiatives of youth-led organizations impacting their local communities.

Story by Josef Henri Tumbagahan
Publication materials courtesy of Order of Asclepius and WVSU Development Communicators’ SocietyFacebook

NEWS UPDATE: Classes at West Visayas State University (WVSU) - Main Campus are suspended on Friday, August 16, 2024, from 7 a.m. onwards for the University Freshmen Orientation (UFO) and Orgs Fest.  
All students, faculty, and non-teaching staff are invited to attend the opening program of the UFO on Friday at 8 a.m. at the WVSU Cultural Center, according to a memorandum dated August 8.  
Meanwhile, the Orgs Fest, scheduled for the afternoon, will be held at the WVSU Grounds.
The WVSU University Student Council has also released the seating arrangements for each department during the UFO, as well as the organization booth placements for Orgs Fest.
The color coding for freshmen attire is assigned as follows:
• Yellow - College of Arts and Sciences
• Green - College of Business and Management
• Orange - College of Information and Communications Technology
• Maroon - College of Communication
• Blue - College of Education
• Pink - College of Nursing
• Purple - College of PESCAR
• Black - College of Dentistry
With the theme, “Bida Ka, Taga West: Ang Unang Kabanata sa Makulay na Paglalakbay,” UFO is an annual event that welcomes first-year students to WVSU and introduces them to its mission, vision, and core values. 
On the other hand, Orgs Fest serves as an avenue for promoting the interests of different organizations, clubs, and groups in the University.
Story by Josef Henri Tumbagahan
Publication materials courtesy of WVSU University Student CouncilFacebook

NEWS UPDATE: 𝗜𝗹𝗼𝗶𝗹𝗼 𝗲𝘆𝗲𝘀 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗰𝗮𝗹𝗮𝗺𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗹𝗮𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗮𝗺𝗶𝗱𝘀𝘁 𝗱𝗲𝗻𝗴𝘂𝗲 𝗼𝘂𝘁𝗯𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗸
The sharp rise in dengue cases in the Province of Iloilo has prompted the Provincial Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council (PDRRMC) to recommend the declaration of a state of calamity, August 15.
The PDRRMC passed a resolution to the Sangguniang Panlalawigan, citing that the province meets the criteria for such a declaration.
If approved, the declaration will enable local government units (LGUs) to utilize their calamity funds.
Iloilo Governor Arthur Defensor Jr. also issued Executive Order No. 74 on August 16, implementing heightened response measures against the disease.
The order requests LGU to reactivate their local dengue task force and “Aksyon sa Barangay Kontra Dengue” to eliminate possible breeding areas for Aedes mosquitoes.
The black-and-white-striped Aedes aegypti mosquito, which thrives in urban environments with stagnant water, is the primary culprit for the disease.
The Provincial Epidemiological Surveillance Unit of the Iloilo Provincial Health Office (IPHO) recorded 4,585 cases from January 1 to August 10 this year.
This number is 319% higher compared to last year’s record of 1,095 cases.
In addition, the same data revealed that 10 deaths have been recorded during the period, higher than only one death in the previous year.
According to the IPHO, 36 out of 43 local government units have already reached the epidemic threshold due to the surge of dengue hemorrhagic fever. 
The LGUs of Tigbauan, Miagao, and Passi City have already declared a state of calamity due to the continuous rise in dengue cases.
Story by Marionn Jed Bernas 
Design by Justin Kyle Quinesio

BALITA: 𝗣𝗡𝗣 𝗽𝗶𝗻𝗮𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗴𝗮𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗴 𝗪𝗩𝗦𝗨 𝗖𝗮𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗼𝗴 𝗖𝗮𝗺𝗽𝘂𝘀 𝗻𝗮 𝗺𝗮𝘆 ‘𝗖𝗣𝗣 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁’
Pinaratangan na may nangyayaring “recruitment activities” ng Communist Party of the Philippines (CPP) ang West Visayas State University (WVSU) - Calinog Campus sa isinagawang Committee on Public Order and Dangerous Drugs hearing na pinamumunuan ni Senador Ronald “Bato” Dela Rosa, Agosto 6.
Ayon sa naging ulat ni Philippine National Police (PNP) Directorate for Operations Col. Randy Arceo, kasama ang WVSU - Calinog Campus sa 102 institusyon na may mga sumuko o nahuling mga miyembro ng New People’s Army.
Bukod pa rito, napasama rin ang kampus sa listahan ng 23 paaralan at unibersidad kung saan higit sa isang beses ang kaso ng recruitment batay sa datos na inilahad.
Dagdag pa ng PNP na nakatala ng dalawang “surenderees” ang WVSU - Calinog Campus, dahilan upang umakyat ito sa ika-15 pwesto.
Kalakip din sa mga pinaratangan sa isang bahagi ng Senate hearing ang University of the Philippines - Visayas, Capiz State University - Dumarao Campus, at iba pang mga paaralan sa buong bansa.
Napag-alaman sa datos ng PNP na ang Putian National High School sa Cuartero, Capiz ang may pinakamataas na bilang ng mga sumuko na umabot sa 10.
Naiulat sa isinagawang hearing na noong 2014 pa lamang ay mayroon nang aktibong pagre-recruit ng mga mag-aaral sa mga nasambit na institusyon.
Dagdag pa rito, sa mahigit 160 estudyanteng natukoy, 36 ang nasawi sa engkwentro, 41 ang naaresto, at 92 ang nag-surrender, ayon sa kabuuang ulat ng PNP at ng Armed Forces of the Philippines.  
Ang nasabing hearing ay alinsunod sa Senate Resolution No. 863, o ang pagpapatupad ng Anti-Terrorism Act of 2020 sa mga paaralan at unibersidad.
Nagsimula ang paglakas ng kampanyang kontra-insurhensya ng bansa sa pagpapatupad ni dating Pangulong Rodrigo Duterte ng Executive Order No. 70 noong December 4, 2018.
Nagtatag ang naturang utos ng National Task Force to End Local Communist Armed Conflict, na pinalakas ng Anti-Terror Law.
Matatandaan na pinirmahan ni dating Pangulong Duterte ang kontrobersiyal na Anti-Terror Law noong Hulyo 3, 2020.
Balita ni Timothy James Sampang
Disenyo ni Justin Kyle Quinesio

𝐅𝐄𝐀𝐓𝐔𝐑𝐄𝐒 | 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗿𝘆 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗿𝘆𝘁𝗲𝗹𝗹𝗲𝗿: 𝗛𝗼𝘄 𝗮 𝗵𝗼𝗯𝗯𝘆 𝗯𝗲𝗰𝗮𝗺𝗲 𝗽𝗮𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗻𝘁𝘂𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆, 𝗽𝘂𝗿𝗽𝗼𝘀𝗲

Life, like photography, is about finding the light in shadows and the beauty in the mundane. It is in these snapshots of time that we muster the courage to take flight, transcend the ordinary, and unfurl our dreams against the boundless sky.

In an era where every moment holds the power to tell stories that words cannot convey, Bryan Rallos, a Taga-West alumnus from Himamaylan City Campus, stands out not just for his ability to capture images, but for his gift in telling tales without uttering a single word.

𝗥𝗼𝗼𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗽𝗮𝗿𝗸

Rallos' journey into photography began not with a camera in hand, but with a promise in his heart. It started during his elementary years, when he watched a classmate, who was a student journalist at the time, freeze moments with a camera. Although he wasn't able to wield one himself back then, he swore that one day, he would be the person behind the lens.

It wasn't until his years as a senior high student that Rallos' fascination with photography resurfaced and allowed him to turn it into a hobby. With nothing but an old Android phone to capture photos of his classmates, Rallos began to understand the unique language that the art of photography speaks.

During the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, Rallos took time to learn more about photography. With the help of his cousins, they would do photoshoots for fun, and he enjoyed every moment of it.

Despite his clear interest in multimedia arts, Rallos pursued a degree in education, with a major in English. Although it wasn't in line with his current craft, it did not mean the end of his photographic journey, because eventually, he became a freelance photographer.

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗯𝗲𝗮𝘂𝘁𝘆 𝗼𝗳 𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗿𝘆𝘁𝗲𝗹𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗴

For Rallos, photography has become a passion and a means of self-expression, as it heals him every time he translates his thoughts into beautiful photographs.

The adrenaline rush he feels while holding a camera is matched only by the satisfaction of creating images that tell stories aligning with his creative vision as an artist.

“Storytelling is one of the keys to an effective image. You are providing doors for viewers to interpret your work and lead them to stories that sometimes differ based on their personal experiences—and that’s the beauty of storytelling,” he shared.

For him, the culture one is exposed to deeply influences their craft. In his case, the dreamy quality of his photos is a signature style. He also often seeks out new faces and models to capture diverse visuals and reflect their unique personalities through his lens.

𝗛𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝗼𝗻𝗲'𝘀 𝗰𝗿𝗮𝗳𝘁

During his college years, time management was among Rallos’ biggest challenges. Balancing his roles as a freelance photographer, student leader, and member of the student publication demanded a great deal of effort.

Despite the exhaustion, it was fulfilling to see the significant growth he experienced through these endeavors. “As long as I’m happy, enjoy what I’m doing, and it pays my bills, that’s all that matters to me,” he said.

Although he doesn’t see teaching as a career path, Rallos is currently reviewing for the boards, believing that obtaining the license will benefit him in the future. Once licensed, he plans to explore opportunities in multimedia arts and hopes to join media and production companies as well as the creative commercial industry.

𝗕𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗴𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀

Rallos envisions a lifetime dedicated to his passion, aiming to broaden his market and visibility. He dreams of one day owning a studio and contributing to major campaigns and magazines globally.

When asked what advice he would give to his younger self, Rallos said, “Have patience. Things may seem a bit blurry now, but trust the process and savor every step. You're bound for bigger and greater things.”

After all, to dream is to have wings, lifted by the sheer force of one's hopes and ambitions. One day, Rallos, the dreamer, will look back at the photos he has taken—each one a shimmering fragment of his journey, capturing moments of what once was and reflecting the person he has become.

Story by Marionn Jed Bernas and Verna Crissa Villorente
Design and layout by Justin Kyle Quinesio
Photo courtesy of Bryan Rallos

NEWS FEATURE: 𝗧𝗮𝗴𝗮-𝗪𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗴𝗮𝗺𝗲 𝗱𝗲𝘃𝘀 𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗿𝗴𝗲 𝗮𝘀 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗺𝗽𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝗮𝘁 𝗢𝗱𝘆𝘀𝘀𝗲𝘆 𝗙𝗲𝘀𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗮𝗹
The Visayan Voyagers, a group of Taga-West Computer Science students, brought pride to the University in a recent triumph at the Odyssey Festival 2024 held at SM City Iloilo, from August 10 to 11.
Driven by years of self-study and hands-on experience in game development, second-year students Lean Vince Cabales, Ken Meiro Villarreal, Zuriel Eliazar Calix, Kurt Allen Alorro, and Allyn Ralf Ledesma, have now found themselves in a well-deserved spotlight.
“One thing led to another—programming became a hobby, then a side hustle, and eventually a passion,” shared Villarreal.
𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗱𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗺 𝘁𝗲𝗮𝗺
The team's journey began when Cabales and Villarreal sought out talented individuals to join them to participate in a contest last year. Ledesma, Alorro, and Calix were recruited to complete the team, with Ledesma serving as the project manager and the others contributing their unique artistic and technical skills.
Fueled by their love for games such as Minecraft and Roblox, they decided to create their own and join game developing competitions. 
“We wanted to gain experience in developing games within a limited time frame and pitching them on stage,” shared Cabales.
For the Odyssey, they developed “Pacmania: Chomp and Brawl,” a revamped game that merges the classic arcade hits Pac-Man and Mortal Kombat, featuring a unique 1v1 mode split into “Labyrinth” and “Brawl Fight.”
This reimagining aims to blend nostalgic elements with enhanced strategic play, offering a fresh experience for both Pac-Man fans and competitive gamers. 
During their freshman year, the team also released “Visayan Sojourn,” an alchemy-based cooking game on Android through the Google Play Store last April.
The Visayan Voyagers want their games to be a source of joy for the people, as they believe that games are created mainly for fun and entertainment.
𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗵𝘂𝗿𝗱𝗹𝗲𝘀
Creating games presented its fair share of challenges for The Visayan Voyagers. Time management emerged as a crucial issue, as the team struggled to balance academic responsibilities with the demanding nature of game development.
“We didn’t really have proper management in developing those games,” Cabales admitted. But despite these hurdles, the team managed to pull through in the final stages of development.
For Calix, venturing into pixel art for “Pacmania” was a memorable challenge, as it was his first foray into the artistic medium. Meanwhile, Alorro, who is responsible for the game's promotional material, struggled with an art block during the summer vacation but managed to find inspiration and complete the work. 
On the other hand, Ledesma emphasized the difficulty of meeting deadlines and the importance of effective task management tools like Trello to keep the project organized and on schedule. 
“It is hectic to balance schoolwork and academic life with competitions. You need to squeeze every bit of energy just to finish,” Ledesma shared.
𝗔 𝗯𝗿𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁 𝗳𝘂𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲
The Visayan Voyagers' adventure in game development has been a journey of growth and discovery. Through their experiences, they have gained profound insights into the nuances of team dynamics, the importance of assigning roles effectively, and the art of balancing time and vision throughout the project lifecycle.
They hope that their story will inspire other students to pursue their passions and embrace the challenges that come with it. They are eager to participate in future hackathons and make their mark across multiple domains of the tech industry, including digital art and other innovative fields.
“Try and try; there are no losses, only wins and lessons,” advised Ledesma to aspiring game developers. The team also recommends familiarizing oneself with game engines for effective programming.
“Losing is normal, and sometimes things are outside of our control. Make [every] loss your motivation,” Cabales added.
What the future holds for them is yet to be seen, but the team is set to sail onto brighter and broader horizons. 
The Visayan Voyagers will continue to blaze trails, proving that dreams are within reach for those who dare to pursue them.
Story by Verna Crissa Villorente 
Layout by Yshi Mei Pomarejos
Design by Justin Kyle Quinesio
Photos courtesy of Little Eye

NEWS FEATURE: 𝗔𝗯𝗼𝘃𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗕𝗲𝘆𝗼𝗻𝗱: 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗣𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗶𝗱𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗪𝗵𝗼 𝗥𝗮𝗶𝘀𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗕𝗮𝗿
“I want to be remembered as the university president who raised the bar.”
Dr. Joselito F. Villaruz, or “Doc Bebong” to his family, friends, and colleagues, holds this vision as the eighth president of West Visayas State University (WVSU).
In a profession that demands both intellect and compassion like medicine, achieving exemplary stature remains a rare feat, and Doc Bebong is among the few who embody this rarity. Recognized as one of the 2024 Dr. Jose Rizal Memorial Awardees, Doc Bebong exceptionally emulates the ideals of the national hero in his life, practice, and service.
𝗣𝗲𝗱𝗶𝗮𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗰𝗶𝗮𝗻 𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗻𝗲𝗱 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿
Unknown to some, Doc Bebong’s dreams set sail on the vast ocean, imagining life as a seafarer as a child. It was only in high school that he began envisioning a future in medicine. His vision of contributing to positive change soon flourished at the University of the Philippines Visayas, where he completed his degree in Biology.
In his second year at WVSU, a spark ignited by his teachers guided him toward pediatrics. Pediatricians, he believes, are “doctors with a very keen sense and acute clinical skills.” This specialty molded him to always see the bigger picture, shaping him into an effective leader and manager. 
Doc Bebong’s career peaked when he assumed the role of officer-in-charge president from November 2013 to May 2014. Despite the brevity of his tenure, he left an indelible mark on the University, paving the way for his appointment as president of WVSU in 2019.
𝗜𝗻 𝗽𝘂𝗿𝘀𝘂𝗶𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗲𝘅𝗰𝗲𝗹𝗹𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲
Initially, Doc Bebong saw the deanship of the University’s College of Medicine as the zenith of his career. However, as he ascended to the presidency, he uncovered deeper layers of purpose and expectations.
“To assume such a position also satisfies an individual’s hunger for self-actualization,” he explained.
Despite facing challenges that tested his abilities, Doc Bebong remained steadfast, believing that while certain obstacles are beyond control, his response always exemplified his best efforts and an acceptance of circumstances.
For Doc Bebong, his latest achievement stands as the pinnacle of his career, a testament to his dedication to the medical field and the academe. He sees his recent distinction as a beacon of excellence, driving his commitment to service and continuous improvement.
𝗕𝗲𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗱 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘆 𝘀𝘂𝗰𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗳𝘂𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝗻
With all great achievements, one might wonder what lies beneath it all. In Doc Bebong’s story, his wife has been the most influential person—his go-to person in times of self-doubt and critical decisions. 
He also cherishes the birth of his first grandchild as the most meaningful moment in his life, saying, “I appreciate now why we exist, why we are living, [and] the continuity of life.”  
When asked about the secret to choosing the right path, Doc Bebong emphasized the need for focus, drive, and motivation. 
“Life is all about choices. No amount of challenge can prevent an individual from achieving his or her dreams,” he stated.
The future may be uncertain, but the University president’s promise remains clear: to push beyond the ordinary in his pursuit of service and excellence, ensuring that WVSU remains as a beacon of quality education, research, and leadership.
Story by Verna Crissa Villorente
Design by Justin Kyle Quinesio
Layout by Keminova Acepcion
